title: PayPal
content:
{{pp-pc|small=yes}} {{Short description|American multinational financial technology company}} {{redirect|Pay Pal|The Simpsons episode|Pay Pal (The Simpsons)}}{{Use American English|date=November 2015}} {{Use mdy dates|date=July 2016}} {{Infobox company | name = PayPal Holdings, Inc. | logo = PayPal.svg | image = PayPal San Jose Headquarters.jpg | image_size = 250px | image_caption = Headquarters in [[San Jose, California]] | type = [[Public company|Public]] | traded_as = {{ubl | {{NASDAQ|PYPL}} | [[Nasdaq-100]] component | [[S&P 100]] component | [[S&P 500]] component }} | founded = {{ubl | {{start date and age|1998|12}} (as [[Confinity]]) | {{start date and age|1999|10}} (as [[X.com (bank)|X.com]]) | {{start date and age|2000|03}} (as PayPal) }} | predecessors = {{ubl | [[Confinity]] | [[X.com (bank)|X.com]] }} | location = [[San Jose, California]], U.S. | area_served = Almost worldwide | founders = {{ubl | [[Ken Howery]] | [[Max Levchin]] | [[Luke Nosek]] | [[Yu Pan]] | [[Peter Thiel]] | [[Elon Musk]] | Harris Fricker | Christopher Payne | Ed Ho }} | key_people = {{ubl | [[John Donahoe]]
([[Chairman#Public corporations|chairman]]) | Alex Chriss
([[President (corporate title)|president]] and [[Chief executive officer|CEO]]){{cite web|url=https://about.pypl.com/who-we-are/executive-leadership/alex-chriss/default.aspx|title=Executive Leadership |website=PayPal |access-date=2023-09-27 |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230927134509/https://about.pypl.com/who-we-are/executive-leadership/alex-chriss/default.aspx |archive-date= 2023-09-27 }} }} | industry = [[Financial technology]] | products = [[Credit card]]s, [[payment systems]] | revenue = {{increase}} {{US$|29.77 billion|link=yes}} (2023) | operating_income = {{increase}} {{US$|5.028 billion}} (2023) | net_income = {{increase}} {{US$|4.246 billion}} (2023) | assets = {{increase}} {{US$|82.17 billion}} (2023) | equity = {{increase}} {{US$|21.05 billion}} (2023) | num_employees = 27,200 (2023) | parent = | divisions = {{ubl | PayPal Inc. (PPI) | PayPal Pte. Ltd (3PL) | PayPal Payments Pte. Holdings (PPLUX) | PayPal Payments Pte Limited (4PL) }} | subsid = {{hlist | [[Braintree (company)|Braintree]] | [[PayPal Honey]] | [[Paydiant]] | [[PayPal Credit]] | [[Tradera]] | [[Venmo]] | [[Xoom Corporation]] | [[Zettle]] }} | website = {{URL|paypal.com}} | footnotes = {{cite web |title=PayPal Holdings, Inc. 2023 Annual Report (Form 10-K) |url=https://www.sec.gov/ix?doc=/Archives/edgar/data/1633917/000163391724000024/pypl-20231231.htm |date=8 February 2024 |publisher=[[U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission]] |access-date=February 11, 2024}} }} [[File:EBayTorontoOffice2.JPG|thumb|upright|[[eBay]], PayPal, [[Kijiji]] and [[StubHub]], [[King Street (Toronto)|500 King Street West]], [[Toronto]], April 2014]] '''PayPal Holdings, Inc.''' is an American multinational financial technology company operating an online payments system in the majority of countries that support [[E-commerce payment system|online money transfers]]; it serves as an electronic alternative to traditional [[Banknote|paper]] methods such as [[cheque|checks]] and [[money order]]s. The company operates as a payment processor for online vendors, [[auction]] sites and many other commercial users, for which it charges a fee. Established in 1998 as Confinity,{{Cite news|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/ryanmac/2012/05/01/reid-hoffman-and-peter-thiel-in-conversation-finding-the-best-candidates-for-the-job/|title=Reid Hoffman And Peter Thiel In Conversation: Finding The Best Candidates For The Job|last=Mac|first=Ryan|date=May 1, 2012|work=[[Forbes]]|access-date=2018-02-28|archive-date=March 1, 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180301045528/https://www.forbes.com/sites/ryanmac/2012/05/01/reid-hoffman-and-peter-thiel-in-conversation-finding-the-best-candidates-for-the-job/|url-status=live}} PayPal went public through an [[initial public offering|IPO]] in 2002. It became a wholly owned subsidiary of [[eBay]] later that year, valued at $1.5 billion.{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2002/07/09/business/ebay-to-buy-paypal-a-rival-in-online-payments.html|title=EBay to Buy PayPal, a Rival in Online Payments|last=Richtel|first=Matt|date=July 9, 2002|work=[[The New York Times]]|access-date=November 23, 2014|archive-date=December 28, 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141228065623/http://www.nytimes.com/2002/07/09/business/ebay-to-buy-paypal-a-rival-in-online-payments.html|url-status=live}} In 2015 eBay [[corporate spin-off|spun off]] PayPal to its shareholders, and PayPal became an independent company again.{{Cite web|url=https://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/1633917/000119312515257108/d31081dex105.htm|title=EX-10.5|website=www.sec.gov|access-date=2018-06-16|archive-date=April 16, 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200416115636/https://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/1633917/000119312515257108/d31081dex105.htm|url-status=live}}{{cite web|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-ebay-divestiture/ebay-follows-icahns-advice-plans-paypal-spinoff-in-2015-idUSKCN0HP13D20140930|title=EBay follows Icahn's advice, plans PayPal spinoff in 2015|last1=Seetharaman|first1=Deepa|last2=Mukherjee|first2=Supantha|date=September 30, 2014|website=[[Reuters]]|access-date=April 16, 2021|archive-date=November 20, 2021|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20211120201221/https://www.reuters.com/article/us-ebay-divestiture/ebay-follows-icahns-advice-plans-paypal-spinoff-in-2015-idUSKCN0HP13D20140930|url-status=live}} The company was ranked 143rd on the 2022 [[Fortune 500|''Fortune'' 500]] of the largest United States corporations by revenue.{{cite web|url=https://fortune.com/fortune500/2021/search/|title=Fortune 500 Companies 2021|publisher=fortune.com|access-date=June 23, 2022|archive-date=March 10, 2022|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220310215217/https://fortune.com/fortune500/2021/search/|url-status=live}} Since 2023 PayPal is a member of the [[MACH Alliance]].{{Cite web |author=PayPal |url=https://newsroom.paypal-corp.com/2023-06-29-MACH-Alliance-Announces-PayPal-is-the-First-Company-to-Join-New-Supporter-Membership-Category |title=MACH Alliance Announces PayPal is the First Company to Join New Supporter Membership Category |date=2023-06-29 |website=PayPal |language=en |access-date=2024-01-09}} == History == {{For timeline}} === Early history === The company was originally established by [[Max Levchin]], [[Peter Thiel]], and [[Luke Nosek]] in December 1998 as Fieldlink, later it was renamed [[Confinity]],{{cite web|url=http://www.techrepublic.com/article/how-the-paypal-mafia-redefined-success-in-silicon-valley/|title=How the 'PayPal Mafia' redefined success in Silicon Valley|last=Forrest|first=Conner|date=June 30, 2014|website=TechRepublic|access-date=November 11, 2014|archive-date=November 4, 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141104145525/http://www.techrepublic.com/article/how-the-paypal-mafia-redefined-success-in-silicon-valley/|url-status=live}} a company which developed security software for hand-held devices.{{Cite web|url=https://www.ft.com/content/86432398-4897-11e4-9d04-00144feab7de|title=Timeline: The rise of PayPal|first=Mark|last=Odell|website=Financial Times|date=30 September 2014|access-date=10 October 2023}} When it had no success with that business model, it switched its focus to a digital wallet.{{cite web|url=http://www.entrepreneur.com/article/228206|title=What PayPal's Rocky Beginnings Can Teach You About Startup Success|last=Cohan|first=Peter S.|date=September 5, 2013|website=Entrepreneur Magazine|access-date=11 November 2014|archive-date=November 12, 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141112035042/http://www.entrepreneur.com/article/228206|url-status=live}} The first version of the PayPal electronic payments system was launched in 1999.{{Cite web|url=http://www.fundinguniverse.com/company-histories/paypal-inc-history/|title=History of PayPal Inc. – FundingUniverse|access-date=November 12, 2014|archive-date=November 11, 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201111223511/http://www.fundinguniverse.com/company-histories/paypal-inc-history/|url-status=live}} In March 2000, Confinity merged with [[x.com (bank)|X.com]], an online financial services company founded in March 1999 by [[Elon Musk]], Harris Fricker, Christopher Payne, and Ed Ho.{{cite web|url=http://www.fastcompany.com/1837839/reid-hoffman-paypals-pivoted-path-success|title=Reid Hoffman On PayPal's Pivoted Path To Success|last=Penenberg|first=Adam L.|date=August 9, 2012|website=Fast Company|access-date=November 11, 2014|archive-date=November 12, 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141112041416/http://www.fastcompany.com/1837839/reid-hoffman-paypals-pivoted-path-success|url-status=live}} Musk was optimistic about the future success of the money transfer business Confinity was developing.{{Cite book|last=Jackson|first=Eric M.|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=uTq5LqBP0IoC&q=history+of+paypal|title=The PayPal Wars: Battles with EBay, the Media, the Mafia and the Rest of Planet Earth|date=2006|publisher=WND Books|isbn=978-0-9778984-3-5|language=en}} Musk and Bill Harris, then-president and CEO of X.com, disagreed about the potential future success of the money transfer business and Harris left the company in May 2000.{{Cite book|last=Gardner|first=James A.|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=dXoYuInfkP0C&q=history+of+paypal&pg=PT65|title=Innovation and the Future Proof Bank: A Practical Guide to Doing Different Business-as-Usual|date=2011-04-20|publisher=John Wiley & Sons|isbn=978-0-470-68521-1|language=en}} In October of that year, Musk decided that X.com would terminate its other internet banking operations and focus on payments.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=iyAbTjqVXgkC|title=The Startup Playbook: Secrets of the Fastest Growing Start-Ups from the founding Entrepreneurs|last1=Kidder|first1=David|last2=Hoffman|first2=Reid|last3=Hindi|first3=Hanny|publisher=Chronicle Books|year=2012|isbn=9781452105048|location=San Francisco, CA|pages=214–216}} In the same month, Elon Musk was replaced by Peter Thiel as CEO of X.com,{{Cite web|url=https://www.cnbc.com/2019/11/02/why-elon-musk-says-taking-vacations-will-kill-you.html|title=Why Elon Musk says taking 'vacations will kill you'|last=Locke|first=Taylor|date=2019-11-02|website=[[CNBC]]|language=en|access-date=2020-03-31|archive-date=September 1, 2021|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210901152911/https://www.cnbc.com/2019/11/02/why-elon-musk-says-taking-vacations-will-kill-you.html|url-status=live}} which was renamed PayPal in June 2001 and went [[IPO|public]] in 2002.{{cite web|url=http://www.businessinsider.com/the-paypal-mafia-is-even-more-powerful-2011-11?op=1|title=Where Are They Now? The PayPal "Mafia" Is More Powerful Than Ever|last=Rosoff|first=Matt|date=November 12, 2011|website=[[Business Insider]]|access-date=11 November 2014|archive-date=October 12, 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141012141949/http://www.businessinsider.com/the-paypal-mafia-is-even-more-powerful-2011-11?op=1|url-status=live}}{{cite news| url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-ebay-divestiture-idUSKCN0HP13D20140930| title=EBay follows Icahn's advice, plans PayPal spinoff in 2015| last1=SEETHARAMAN| first1=DEEPA| last2=MUKHERJEE| first2=SUPANTHA| date=30 September 2014| work=[[Reuters]]| access-date=11 November 2014| archive-date=January 2, 2016| archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160102221610/http://www.reuters.com/article/us-ebay-divestiture-idUSKCN0HP13D20140930| url-status=live}}{{Cite web|url=https://www.theverge.com/2017/7/10/15949862/elon-musk-x-com-paypal-tesla-spacex-domain-name|title=Elon Musk now owns X.com, the defunct domain of his second startup|last=Statt|first=Nick|date=2017-07-10|website=[[The Verge]]|language=en|access-date=2020-03-31|archive-date=June 25, 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200625193958/https://www.theverge.com/2017/7/10/15949862/elon-musk-x-com-paypal-tesla-spacex-domain-name|url-status=live}} PayPal's [[Initial public offering|IPO]] listed under the [[Ticker symbol|ticker]] PYPL at $13 per share and generated over $61 million.{{cite web| url=https://www.ecommercetimes.com/story/16368.html| title=PayPal IPO Off to Spectacular Start| author=Keith Regan| date=15 February 2002| publisher=ECommerce Times| access-date=11 November 2014| archive-date=September 7, 2020| archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200907015714/https://www.ecommercetimes.com/story/16368.html| url-status=live}} === eBay subsidiary (2002–2014) === Shortly after PayPal's IPO, [[eBay]] acquired the company on October 3, 2002,{{Cite web|url=https://www.annualreports.com/HostedData/AnnualReportArchive/e/NASDAQ_EBAY_2002.pdf|title=eBay 2002 Annual Report|access-date=January 12, 2021|archive-date=October 26, 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201026040359/https://www.annualreports.com/HostedData/AnnualReportArchive/e/NASDAQ_EBAY_2002.pdf|url-status=live}} for $1.5 billion in eBay stock.{{Cite news|author=Kane, Margaret|title=eBay picks up PayPal for $1.5 billion|url=http://www.news.com/2100-1017-941964.html|date=July 8, 2002|work=CNET News.com|publisher=CNET Networks|access-date=November 13, 2007|archive-date=June 10, 2022|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220610061605/http://news.cnet.com/2100-1017-941964.html?hhTest=1|url-status=dead}}{{cite magazine|url=http://www.fastcompany.com/3036087/unfinished-business-max-levchins-quest-to-build-the-next-paypal |title=UNFINISHED BUSINESS: MAX LEVCHIN'S QUEST TO BUILD THE NEXT PAYPAL |author=Austin Carr |date=16 October 2014 |magazine=Fast Company |access-date=11 November 2014}} More than 70 percent of all eBay auctions accepted PayPal payments, and roughly 1 in 4 closed auction listings were transacted via PayPal.{{cite news |url=https://venturebeat.com/2012/10/27/how-ebays-purchase-of-paypal-changed-silicon-valley/#8cV8y19jcBArQLfE.99 |title=How eBay's purchase of PayPal changed Silicon Valley |newspaper=Venturebeat |publisher=Venture Beat |date=October 27, 2012 |access-date=October 28, 2012 |archive-date=October 28, 2012 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121028170929/http://venturebeat.com/2012/10/27/how-ebays-purchase-of-paypal-changed-silicon-valley/#8cV8y19jcBArQLfE.99 |url-status=live }} PayPal became the default payment method used by the majority of eBay users, and the service competed with eBay's subsidiary [[Billpoint]], as well as [[Citibank]]'s c2it, [[Yahoo!]]'s [[PayDirect]], and [[Google Checkout]]. In 2005, PayPal acquired the [[VeriSign]] payment solution to provide added security support.{{cite web |url=https://www.ecommercetimes.com/story/46648.html |title=Eyeing Expansion of PayPal, eBay Buys VeriSign Payment Gateway |author=Keith Regan |date=11 October 2005 |publisher=ECommerce Times |access-date=11 November 2014 |archive-date=October 25, 2020 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201025093830/https://www.ecommercetimes.com/story/46648.html |url-status=live }} In 2007, PayPal announced a partnership with [[MasterCard]], which led to the development and launch of the PayPal Secure Card service, a software that allows customers to make payments on websites that do not accept PayPal directly.{{cite news |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-ebay-paypal-ecommerce-idUSN1840572920071119 |title=PayPal offers secure way to shop non-PayPal sites |author=Eric Auchard |date=19 November 2007 |work=[[Reuters]]|access-date=11 November 2014 |archive-date=September 22, 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210922211530/https://www.reuters.com/article/us-ebay-paypal-ecommerce-idUSN1840572920071119 |url-status=live }} By the end of 2007, the company generated $1.8 billion in revenue.{{cite web |url=https://money.cnn.com/2008/02/26/smbusiness/paypal_float.fsb/ |title=What PayPal does with your money |author=Lenora Chu |date=26 February 2008 |website=CNN Money |access-date=11 November 2014 |archive-date=November 9, 2020 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201109033057/https://money.cnn.com/2008/02/26/smbusiness/paypal_float.fsb/ |url-status=live }} In January 2008, PayPal acquired [[Fraud Sciences]], a privately held Israeli start-up that developed online risk tools, for $169 million.{{cite news |url=https://techcrunch.com/2008/01/28/ebay-acquires-fraud-sciences-for-169-million/ |title=eBay Acquires Fraud Sciences For $169 Million |author=Peter Ha |date=28 January 2008 |work=[[TechCrunch]] |access-date=11 November 2014 |archive-date=November 27, 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181127125218/https://techcrunch.com/2008/01/28/ebay-acquires-fraud-sciences-for-169-million/ |url-status=live }}{{Cite web|url=https://archive.nytimes.com/www.nytimes.com/idg/IDG_002570DE00740E18002573DE00422DAA.html|title=PayPal Buys Fraud Sciences for $169 Million – New York Times|last1=Kirk|first1=Jeremy|last2=Bureau|first2=IDG News Service\London|website=archive.nytimes.com|access-date=31 March 2020|last3=IDG|archive-date=September 6, 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200906202448/https://archive.nytimes.com/www.nytimes.com/idg/IDG_002570DE00740E18002573DE00422DAA.html|url-status=live}} In November 2008, the company acquired [[Bill Me Later]], an online transactional credit company.{{cite web |url=http://www.inc.com/mike-hofman/2008/10/ebay_buys_bill_me_later_for_ne.html |title=EBay Buys Bill Me Later for Nearly $1 Billion |author=MIKE HOFMAN |date=7 October 2008 |publisher=Inc Magazine |access-date=11 November 2014 |archive-date=November 12, 2014 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141112053835/http://www.inc.com/mike-hofman/2008/10/ebay_buys_bill_me_later_for_ne.html |url-status=live }} By 2010, PayPal had over 100 million active user accounts in 190 markets through 25 different currencies.{{cite book |title=Gale Encyclopedia of E-Commerce, 2nd Edition |publisher=Gale |date=June 2012 |isbn=9781414490465}} In July 2011, fourteen alleged members of the [[Anonymous (group)|Anonymous]] [[hacktivist]] group were charged with attempting to disrupt PayPal's operations. The [[denial of service]] attacks occurred in December 2010, after PayPal stopped processing donations to [[WikiLeaks]]. On 5 December 2013, 13 of the [[PayPal 14]] pleaded guilty to misdemeanor and felony charges related to the attacks.{{cite news |url=http://www.ibtimes.co.uk/articles/528058/20131206/paypal-14-freedom-fighters-plead-guilty-cyber.htm |author=David Gilbert |title=PayPal 14 'Freedom Fighters' Plead Guilty to Cyber-Attack |work=International Business Times |date=6 December 2013 |access-date=December 9, 2013 |archive-date=December 9, 2013 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131209025021/http://www.ibtimes.co.uk/articles/528058/20131206/paypal-14-freedom-fighters-plead-guilty-cyber.htm |url-status=live }}{{cite web |url=http://news.cnet.com/8301-1009_3-57614906-83/anonymous-hackers-plead-guilty-to-2010-paypal-cyberattack/ |author=Steven Musil |title=Anonymous hackers plead guilty to 2010 PayPal cyberattack |publisher=Cnet |date=8 December 2013 |access-date=December 9, 2013 |archive-date=December 11, 2013 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131211005617/http://news.cnet.com/8301-1009_3-57614906-83/anonymous-hackers-plead-guilty-to-2010-paypal-cyberattack/ |url-status=live }} The company continued to build its Merchant Services division, providing [[e-payment]]s for retailers on eBay. In 2011, PayPal announced that it would begin moving its business offline so that customers can make payments via PayPal in stores.Verne Kopytoff, ''The New York Times''. "[http://bits.blogs.nytimes.com/2011/09/15/paypal-prepares-for-a-move-offline/?ref=technology PayPal Prepares to Expand Offline] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111024094217/http://bits.blogs.nytimes.com/2011/09/15/paypal-prepares-for-a-move-offline/?ref=technology |date=October 24, 2011 }}", 15 September 2011. Retrieved 16 September 2011. In August 2012, the company announced its partnership with [[Discover Card]] to allow PayPal payments to be made at any of the seven million stores in the Discover network.{{cite web |url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/chrisbarth/2012/08/22/discover-and-paypal-join-forces-in-the-war-against-paper-money-banks/ |title=Discover And PayPal Join Forces In The War Against Paper Money, Banks |author=Chris Barth |date=22 August 2012 |work=[[Forbes]]|access-date=11 November 2014 |archive-date=October 30, 2020 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201030001711/https://www.forbes.com/sites/chrisbarth/2012/08/22/discover-and-paypal-join-forces-in-the-war-against-paper-money-banks/ |url-status=live }} By the end of 2012, PayPal's total payment volume processed was {{USD|145 billion}}.[https://www.paypal-media.com/about About PayPal – PayPal] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130115041302/https://www.paypal-media.com/about |date=January 15, 2013 }}. Paypal-media.com. Retrieved 12 August 2013. and accounted for 40% of eBay's revenue, amounting to {{USD|1.37 billion}} in the 3rd quarter of 2012. In 2013, PayPal acquired IronPearl, a [[Palo Alto]] startup offering engagement software,{{cite news |url=https://venturebeat.com/2013/04/11/paypal-buys-iron-pearl/ |title=PayPal buys young startup Iron Pearl to help it acquire more users |author=Sean Ludwig |date=11 April 2013 |work=VentureBeat |access-date=11 November 2014 |archive-date=October 24, 2020 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201024210437/https://venturebeat.com/2013/04/11/paypal-buys-iron-pearl/ |url-status=live }} and [[Braintree (company)|Braintree]], a [[Chicago]]-based [[payment gateway]], to further product development and mobile services.{{cite news |url=https://techcrunch.com/2013/09/26/paypal-acquires-payments-gateway-braintree-for-800m-in-cash/ |title=EBay's PayPal Acquires Payments Gateway Braintree For $800M In Cash |author=Leena Rao |date=26 September 2013 |work=[[TechCrunch]] |access-date=11 November 2014 |archive-date=July 5, 2017 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170705204605/https://techcrunch.com/2013/09/26/paypal-acquires-payments-gateway-braintree-for-800m-in-cash/ |url-status=live }} In June 2014 [[David A. Marcus|David Marcus]] announced he was leaving his role{{Cite news|url=http://www.businessinsider.com/paypal-president-david-marcus-joins-facebook-2014-6|title=PayPal President David Marcus Is Stepping Down To Join Facebook|author=Jillian D'Onfro|work=[[Business Insider]]|date=June 9, 2014|access-date=July 2, 2014|archive-date=November 30, 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181130135935/https://www.businessinsider.com/paypal-president-david-marcus-joins-facebook-2014-6|url-status=live}} as PayPal President; Marcus joined PayPal in August 2011 after its acquisition of [[Zong mobile payments|Zong]], of which he was the founder and CEO.{{cite news |author=Tricia Duryee |work=AllThingsD.com |url=http://allthingsd.com/20120329/ebay-promotes-david-marcus-to-fill-top-vacancy-at-paypal |title=eBay Promotes David Marcus to Fill Top Vacancy at PayPal |date=March 29, 2012 |access-date=October 14, 2012 |publisher=[[Dow Jones & Company|Dow Jones]] |archive-date=October 13, 2012 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121013051945/http://allthingsd.com/20120329/ebay-promotes-david-marcus-to-fill-top-vacancy-at-paypal/ |url-status=live }} David Marcus succeeded [[Scott Thompson (businessman)|Scott Thompson]] as president, who left the role to join [[Yahoo]]. PayPal announced that Marcus would be succeeded by [[Dan Schulman]], who previously served as CEO of [[Virgin Mobile]] and Executive vice president of [[American Express]].{{cite web |url=http://www.bizjournals.com/sanjose/news/2014/09/30/who-the-heck-is-dan-schulman-paypals-new-ceo.html?page=all |title=Meet PayPal CEO-to-be Schulman: Homelessness exercise as a management tool |author=Cromwell Schubarth |date=30 September 2014 |work=Silicon Valley Business Journal |access-date=11 November 2014 |archive-date=November 12, 2014 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141112072012/http://www.bizjournals.com/sanjose/news/2014/09/30/who-the-heck-is-dan-schulman-paypals-new-ceo.html?page=all |url-status=live }} === Spin-off from eBay (2014–present) === It was announced on September 30, 2014, that eBay would spin off PayPal into a separate publicly traded company, a move demanded in 2013 by activist [[hedge fund]] magnate [[Carl Icahn]]. The spin-off was completed on July 18, 2015.{{cite news|last1=De La Merced|first1=Michael|last2=Sorkin|first2=Andrew|title=EBay to Spin Off PayPal, Adopting Strategy Backed by Icahn|url=https://dealbook.nytimes.com/2014/09/30/ebay-to-spin-off-paypal-adopting-strategy-backed-by-icahn/?_php=true&_type=blogs&_r=0|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|date=September 30, 2014|access-date=30 September 2014|archive-date=November 14, 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201114204227/https://dealbook.nytimes.com/2014/09/30/ebay-to-spin-off-paypal-adopting-strategy-backed-by-icahn/?_php=true&_type=blogs&_r=0|url-status=live}}{{cite news|last1=Mukherjee|first1=Supantha|title=EBay follows Icahn's advice, plans PayPal spinoff in 2015|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-ebay-divestiture-idUSKCN0HP13D20140930|work=[[Reuters]]|access-date=30 September 2014|archive-date=January 2, 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160102221610/http://www.reuters.com/article/us-ebay-divestiture-idUSKCN0HP13D20140930|url-status=live}}{{cite web|last1=Cheng|first1=Roger|title=eBay, PayPal to split into separate companies in 2015|url=https://www.cnet.com/news/ebay-to-split-paypal-into-separate-company-in-2015/|website=[[CNET]]|access-date=30 September 2014|archive-date=June 12, 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180612164755/https://www.cnet.com/news/ebay-to-split-paypal-into-separate-company-in-2015/|url-status=live}} [[Dan Schulman]] is the current president and CEO, with former eBay CEO [[John Donahoe]] serving as chairman. On January 31, 2018, eBay announced "After the existing eBay-PayPal agreement ends in 2020, PayPal will remain a payment option for shoppers on eBay, but it won't be prominently featured ahead of debit and credit card options as it is today. PayPal will cease to process card payments for eBay at that time." The company will "instead begin working with [[Amsterdam]]-based [[Adyen]]".{{Cite news|url=https://www.recode.net/2018/1/31/16957212/ebay-adyen-paypal-payments-agreement|title=After 15 years, eBay plans to cut off PayPal as its main payments processor|last=Del Rey|first=Jason|date=January 31, 2018|work=[[Recode]]|access-date=2018-02-28|archive-date=February 1, 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180201000955/https://www.recode.net/2018/1/31/16957212/ebay-adyen-paypal-payments-agreement|url-status=live}} On July 1, 2015, PayPal announced that it was acquiring digital money transfer company [[Xoom Corporation]]. PayPal spent $25 a share in cash to acquire the publicly traded Xoom, or about $1.09 billion. The deal was closed in the fourth quarter of 2015. The move strengthened PayPal’s international business, giving it access to Xoom’s 1.3 million active U.S. customers that sent about $7 billion in the 12 months ending on March 31, to people in 37 countries.{{Cite web|title = PayPal acquires money transfer firm Xoom for $890 million|url = http://fortune.com/2015/07/01/paypal-acquires-money-transfer-firm-xoom-for-890-million/|website = Fortune|access-date = 2016-02-11|archive-date = March 8, 2016|archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20160308090216/http://fortune.com/2015/07/01/paypal-acquires-money-transfer-firm-xoom-for-890-million/|url-status = live}}{{Cite news|title = PayPal Acquires Xoom for Stake in Digital Money Transfers|url = https://www.nytimes.com/2015/07/02/business/paypal-acquires-xoom-for-stake-in-digital-money-transfers.html|newspaper = The New York Times|date = 2015-07-01|access-date = 2016-02-11|issn = 0362-4331|first = Nick|last = Wingfield|archive-date = July 9, 2017|archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20170709101553/https://www.nytimes.com/2015/07/02/business/paypal-acquires-xoom-for-stake-in-digital-money-transfers.html|url-status = live}} On September 1, 2015, PayPal launched its [[peer-to-peer]] payment platform "PayPal.Me", a service that allows users to send a custom link to request funds via text, email, or other messaging platforms.{{cite web|last1=Perez|first1=Sarah|title=PayPal Launches PayPal.Me, A Simpler Way To Request Money Using Your Own Personalized URL|url=https://techcrunch.com/2015/09/01/paypal-launches-paypal-me-a-simpler-way-to-request-money-using-your-own-personalized-url/|website=Tech Crunch|date=September 2015|access-date=1 September 2015|archive-date=January 21, 2019|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190121232456/https://techcrunch.com/2015/09/01/paypal-launches-paypal-me-a-simpler-way-to-request-money-using-your-own-personalized-url/|url-status=live}} Custom links are set to be structured as PayPal.me/username/amount requested. PayPal.Me was launched in 18 countries including the United States, United Kingdom, Germany, Australia, Canada, Russia, Turkey, France, Italy, Spain, Poland, Sweden, Belgium, Norway, Denmark, Netherlands, Austria and Switzerland.{{cite web|last1=Brian|first1=Matt|title=PayPal makes it even easier to call in your debts|url=https://www.engadget.com/2015/09/01/paypal-me/|website=engadget|date=September 2015 |access-date=1 September 2015|archive-date=January 21, 2019|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190121175159/https://www.engadget.com/2015/09/01/paypal-me/|url-status=live}} PayPal had 170 million users, as of September 2015, and the focus of PayPal.Me was to create a mobile-first user experience that enables faster payment sharing than PayPal's traditional tools. For fiscal year 2019, Paypal reported earnings of US$2.459 billion, with an annual revenue of $17.772 billion, an increase of 15% over the previous fiscal cycle. PayPal laid off hundreds of workers across US offices and moved jobs overseas during 2020-2022 pandemic. == Offices == [[File:PayPal Headquarters.jpg|thumb|PayPal Operations Center in [[La Vista, Nebraska]]]] PayPal's corporate headquarters are located in the [[North San Jose Innovation District]] of [[San Jose, California]],{{Citation |author=Diana Samuels |date=October 29, 2012 |title=PayPal lays off 325 in effort to speed innovation |periodical=[[San Jose Business Journal]] |at=bizjournals.com |url=http://www.bizjournals.com/sanjose/blog/2012/10/paypal-lays-off-325-in-effort-to-speed.html |access-date=October 30, 2012 |archive-date=September 10, 2020 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200910230723/https://www.bizjournals.com/sanjose/blog/2012/10/paypal-lays-off-325-in-effort-to-speed.html |url-status=live }} at North First Street campus.{{cite web| url=http://www.bizjournals.com/sanjose/news/2013/01/30/ebay-to-expand-presence-in-north-san.html?page=all| title=Fast-growing eBay spreads out in North San Jose| author=Nathan Donato-Weinstein| date=30 January 2013| publisher=San Jose Business Journal| access-date=11 November 2014| archive-date=November 12, 2014| archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141112071703/http://www.bizjournals.com/sanjose/news/2013/01/30/ebay-to-expand-presence-in-north-san.html?page=all| url-status=live}} The company's operations center is located in [[La Vista, Nebraska]], which was opened in 1999.{{cite web| url=http://journalstar.com/business/paypal-center-in-lavista-moves-online-payments-worldwide/article_1f8125ca-7087-5dd7-a854-34f4e32743b8.html| title=PayPal center in LaVista moves online payments worldwide| author=Josh Funk| date=24 June 2007| publisher=JournalStar| access-date=11 November 2014| archive-date=August 5, 2018| archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180805203219/https://journalstar.com/business/paypal-center-in-lavista-moves-online-payments-worldwide/article_1f8125ca-7087-5dd7-a854-34f4e32743b8.html| url-status=live}}Virgil Larson, "Local building, global growth: PayPal opens facility, plans to expand staff to keep up with business", ''[[Omaha World-Herald]]'', March 8, 2007, 1D. Since July 2007, PayPal has operated across the [[European Union]] as a Luxembourg-based bank. The PayPal European headquarters are located in [[Luxembourg]] and the international headquarters are in [[Singapore]]. PayPal opened a technology center in [[Scottsdale, Arizona]] in 2006,{{cite web |url=http://www.auctionbytes.com/cab/abn/y06/m09/i27/s04 |title=eBay CEO Meets with Arizona Governor over PayPal Tech Center |publisher=auctionbytes.com |date=September 27, 2007 |access-date=March 1, 2012 |archive-date=July 20, 2009 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090720011259/http://www.auctionbytes.com/cab/abn/y06/m09/i27/s04 |url-status=live }} and a software development center in [[Chennai]], India in 2007.{{cite web |url=http://www.efytimes.com/e1/fullnews.asp?edid=22523 |title=eBay, PayPal Open Development Facility in Chennai |publisher=efytimes.com |date=November 5, 2007 |access-date=March 1, 2012 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151017051010/http://www.efytimes.com/e1/fullnews.asp?edid=22523 |archive-date=October 17, 2015 |url-status=dead }} In October 2007, PayPal opened a data service office on the north side of [[Austin, Texas]],{{cite news| url=http://www.bizjournals.com/austin/stories/2007/10/15/daily35.html| title=PayPal open for business| date=19 October 2007| newspaper=Austin Business Journal| access-date=11 November 2014| archive-date=November 12, 2014| archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141112070030/http://www.bizjournals.com/austin/stories/2007/10/15/daily35.html| url-status=live}} and also opened a second operations center in [[La Vista, Nebraska]] that same year. In 2011, joining similar customer support operations located in [[Berlin, Germany]]; [[Chandler, Arizona]]; [[Dublin]] and [[Dundalk]], Ireland; [[Omaha, Nebraska]]; and [[Shanghai]], China; PayPal opened a second customer support center in [[Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia]], and began the hiring process.{{cite web|last1=Cheon-Fong|first1=Liew|title=New PayPal Office in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia (and Hiring!)|url=http://www.liewcf.com/paypal-office-job-kl-malaysia-6879/|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110117120724/http://www.liewcf.com/paypal-office-job-kl-malaysia-6879/|url-status=dead|archive-date=17 January 2011|publisher=LiewCF|access-date=26 April 2016}} In 2014, PayPal opened a new global center of operations in Kuala Lumpur.{{cite web|title=Grand Opening Ceremony – PayPal Global Operations Centre [sic] in Malaysia|url=https://www.glassdoor.co.in/Photos/PayPal-Office-Photos-IMG167693.htm|website=glassdoor.co.in, 18 Mar 2014|access-date=April 26, 2016|archive-date=May 13, 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160513004621/https://www.glassdoor.co.in/Photos/PayPal-Office-Photos-IMG167693.htm|url-status=live}} == Services == PayPal's services allow people to make [[financial transaction]]s online by granting the ability to [[electronic funds transfer|transfer funds electronically]] between individuals and businesses.{{cite web| url=http://money.howstuffworks.com/paypal.htm| title=How PayPal Works| last1=Grabianowski| first1=Ed| last2=Crawford| first2=Stephanie| date=December 13, 2005| publisher=How Stuff Works| access-date=23 November 2014| archive-date=November 13, 2006| archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20061113052400/http://money.howstuffworks.com/paypal.htm| url-status=live}} Through PayPal, users can send or receive payments for online auctions on websites like [[eBay]], purchase or sell goods and services, or [[Philanthropy|donate money]] or receive donations. It is not necessary or required to have a PayPal account to use the company's services. Certain packaging may come with [[Tracking number|tracking numbers]]. PayPal account users can set [[Exchange rate|currency conversion]] option in account settings.{{Cite web|url=https://smallbusiness.chron.com/convert-money-paypal-28101.html|title=How to Convert Money in PayPal|website=smallbusiness.chron.com|language=en|access-date=2020-02-19|archive-date=September 7, 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200907174328/https://smallbusiness.chron.com/convert-money-paypal-28101.html|url-status=live}} The PayPal app is available online or at the [[iTunes App Store]] and [[Google Play]]. One year after acquiring [[Braintree (company)|Braintree]], PayPal introduced its "One Touch" service, which allows users to pay with a one-touch option on participating merchants websites or apps.{{cite web| url=http://recode.net/2014/08/19/paypal-introduces-one-touch-mobile-payments-thanks-to-braintree-and-venmo/| title=PayPal Introduces One-Touch Mobile Payments, Thanks to Braintree and Venmo| author=Jason Del Rey| date=19 August 2014| publisher=Recode| access-date=23 November 2014| archive-date=November 22, 2014| archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141122235530/http://recode.net/2014/08/19/paypal-introduces-one-touch-mobile-payments-thanks-to-braintree-and-venmo/| url-status=live}} In 2007, PayPal acquired the online credit product [[Bill me later|Bill Me Later]], Inc.,{{Cite web|title=Ebay Spends More Than $1.2 Billion To Buy Bill Me Later And DBA.dk, And Lays Off 10% Of Employees|url=https://social.techcrunch.com/2008/10/06/ebay-spends-more-than-1-billion-to-buy-billmelater-and-dbadk-and-lays-off-10-of-employees/|access-date=2020-09-21|website=[[TechCrunch]]|date=October 6, 2008 |language=en-US}} which has since been rebranded as PayPal Credit and provided services for [[Alliance Data|Comenity Capital Bank]], the lender of PayPal Credit accounts. Founded in 2000, Bill Me Later is headquartered in [[Timonium, Maryland]].{{Cite web|date=2008-10-06|title=eBay Inc. adds Bill Me Later to Portfolio|url=https://www.ebayinc.com/stories/news/ebay-inc-adds-bill-me-later-to-portfolio/|access-date=2020-09-21|website=www.ebayinc.com|language=en-US|archive-date=October 1, 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201001221757/https://www.ebayinc.com/stories/news/ebay-inc-adds-bill-me-later-to-portfolio/|url-status=live}} PayPal Credit offers shoppers access to an instant online revolving line of credit at thousands of vendors that accept PayPal, subject to credit approval. PayPal Credit allows consumers to shop online in much the same way as they would with a traditional credit card. The rebranding of Bill Me Later as PayPal Credit also means that consumers can use PayPal Credit to fund transactions virtually anywhere PayPal is accepted.{{cite web|url=https://www.billmelater.com/about/index.xhtml|title=Bill Me Later|access-date=5 September 2015|archive-date=March 18, 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150318072233/https://www.billmelater.com/about/index.xhtml|url-status=live}} In 2015 PayPal agreed that PayPal Credit would pay a $25 million fine to settle a complaint filed in Federal Court by the [[Consumer Financial Protection Bureau]].{{cite court |litigants=Consumer Financial Protection Bureau v. Paypal Inc., and Bill Me Later, Inc. |vol=Case 1:15-cv-01426-RDB |opinion=Stipulated Final Judgment and Order |court=United States District Court for the District of Maryland |date=05/21/2015 |url=http://files.consumerfinance.gov/f/201505_cfpb_consent-order-paypal.pdf }} From 2009 to 2016, PayPal operated Student Accounts, allowing parents to set up a student account, transfer money into it, and obtain a debit card for student use. The program provided tools to teach how to spend money wisely and take responsibility for actions.[http://news.softpedia.com/news/PayPal-Creates-Student-Accounts-For-Teens-118965.shtml PayPal Creates Student Accounts for Teens] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110511110505/http://news.softpedia.com/news/PayPal-Creates-Student-Accounts-For-Teens-118965.shtml |date=May 11, 2011 }}. Retrieved October 23, 2010.{{cite news| url=http://bits.blogs.nytimes.com/2008/12/01/paypal-brings-the-weekly-allowance-into-the-21st-century/?_php=true&_type=blogs&_r=1| title=PayPal Brings Allowances Into the 21st Century| author=Brad Stone| date=1 December 2008| newspaper=[[The New York Times]]| access-date=23 November 2014| archive-date=November 29, 2014| archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141129192935/http://bits.blogs.nytimes.com/2008/12/01/paypal-brings-the-weekly-allowance-into-the-21st-century/?_php=true&_type=blogs&_r=1| url-status=live}} PayPal discontinued Student Accounts in August 2016. web |url=http://gigaom.com/2009/11/03/paypals-partially-open-platform-to-usher-in-new-payment-models-apps/ |title=PayPal's (Partially) Open Platform to Usher in New Payment Models & Apps: Tech News [[iOS]] and [[Android (operating system)|Android]] in 2013 that expanded its mobile app capabilities by allowing users to search for local shops and restaurants that accept PayPal payments, order ahead at participating venues, and access their PayPal Credit accounts (formerly known as Bill Me Later). On October 21, 2020, PayPal announced a new service allowing customers to use [[cryptocurrencies]] to shop at 26 million merchants on the network starting in 2021. Paypal has been using [[Paxos Trust Company|Paxos Trust]] to provide the back end infrastructure allowing users to manage and trade cryptocurrencies in accordance to [[Information privacy|data privacy rules]] and financial regulations. Paxos has been in charge of acquiring the necessary regulatory approvals for Paypal to facilitate cryptocurrency assets. As part of the announcement, PayPal secured the first conditional cryptocurrency license from the [[New York State Department of Financial Services]], which will allow customers to purchase cryptocurrencies such as [[Bitcoin]], [[Litecoin]], [[Ethereum]], and [[Bitcoin Cash]].{{cite news |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/paypal-cryptocurrency/paypal-to-allow-cryptocurrency-buying-selling-and-shopping-on-its-network-idINL1N2HB14U |title=PayPal to allow cryptocurrency buying, selling and shopping on its network |work=[[Reuters]] |date=2020-10-21 |access-date=2020-10-21 |archive-date=October 21, 2020 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201021130740/https://www.reuters.com/article/paypal-cryptocurrency/paypal-to-allow-cryptocurrency-buying-selling-and-shopping-on-its-network-idINL1N2HB14U |url-status=live }}{{Cite news|date=2020-10-21|title=PayPal allows Bitcoin and crypto spending|language=en-GB|work=[[BBC News]]|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/technology-54630283|access-date=2020-10-22|archive-date=October 22, 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201022110652/https://www.bbc.com/news/technology-54630283|url-status=live}}{{Cite news|last=Castellanos|first=Sara|date=2021-03-11|title=PayPal's Entry to Crypto Followed Long Buildup in Expertise|language=en-US|work=[[The Wall Street Journal]]|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/paypals-entry-to-crypto-followed-long-buildup-in-expertise-11615503851|access-date=2021-03-20|issn=0099-9660|archive-date=March 20, 2021|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210320112440/https://www.wsj.com/articles/paypals-entry-to-crypto-followed-long-buildup-in-expertise-11615503851|url-status=live}} In March 2022, PayPal introduced a flat-fee structure for cryptocurrency transactions under $200; transactions over $200 incur a 1.8% fee for purchases or sales up to $1,000, and 1.5% for any transaction amount greater than $1,000.{{Cite web |last=Lejeune |first=Tristan |date=2022-03-21 |title=New fees for crypto transactions on PayPal, Venmo go into effect |url=https://thehill.com/policy/technology/599095-new-fees-for-crypto-transactions-on-paypal-venmo-go-into-effect |access-date=2022-03-22 |website=[[The Hill (newspaper)|The Hill]] |language=en |archive-date=March 22, 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220322210843/https://thehill.com/policy/technology/599095-new-fees-for-crypto-transactions-on-paypal-venmo-go-into-effect |url-status=live }} {{As of | 2022}}, PayPal operates in 202 markets and has 426 million active, registered accounts. PayPal allows customers to send, receive, and hold funds in 25 currencies worldwide.{{Cite web|url=https://investor.pypl.com/news-and-events/events/event-details/2022/PayPals-Q4-2021-Earnings-Call/default.aspx|title=PayPal's Q4 2021 Earnings Call|access-date=February 22, 2022|archive-date=February 22, 2022|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220222180234/https://investor.pypl.com/news-and-events/events/event-details/2022/PayPals-Q4-2021-Earnings-Call/default.aspx|url-status=live}} === Business model evolution === PayPal's success in users and volumes was the product of a three-phase strategy described by former eBay CEO [[Meg Whitman]]: "First, PayPal focused on expanding its service among eBay users in the US. Second, we began expanding PayPal to eBay's international sites. And third, we started to build PayPal's business off eBay."{{cite web |url=http://wallstfolly.typepad.com/wallstfolly/2006/01/intel_conferenc.html |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20061116122051/http://wallstfolly.typepad.com/wallstfolly/2006/01/intel_conferenc.html |url-status=dead |archive-date=November 16, 2006 |title=Wall Street Folly: eBay: Conference call transcript – 1/18/06 |publisher=Wallstfolly.typepad.com |access-date=January 20, 2011 }} ==== Phase 1 ==== In the first phase, payment volumes were coming mostly from the eBay auction website. The system was very attractive to auction sellers, most of which were individuals or small businesses that were unable to accept credit cards, and for consumers as well. In fact, many sellers could not qualify for a credit card Merchant account because they lacked a commercial credit history. The service also appealed to auction buyers because they could fund PayPal accounts using credit cards or bank account balances, without divulging credit card numbers to unknown sellers. PayPal employed an aggressive marketing campaign to accelerate its growth, depositing $10 in new users' PayPal accounts. ==== Phase 2 ==== Until 2000, PayPal's strategy was to earn interest on funds in PayPal accounts. However, most recipients of PayPal credits withdrew funds immediately. Also, many senders funded their payments using credit cards, which cost PayPal roughly 2% of payment value per transaction.{{Citation needed|date=November 2017}} To solve this problem, PayPal tailored its product to cater more to business accounts. Instead of relying on interests earned from deposited funds, PayPal started relying on earnings from service charges. They offered seller protection to PayPal account holders, provided that they comply with reimbursement policies. For example, PayPal merchants are either required to retain a traceable proof of shipping to a confirmed address or to provide a signed receipt for items valued over $750.{{Citation needed|date=November 2017}} ==== Phase 3 ==== After fine-tuning PayPal's business model and increasing its domestic and international penetration on eBay, PayPal started its off-eBay strategy. This was based on developing stronger growth in active users by adding users across multiple platforms, despite the slowdown in on-eBay growth and low-single-digit user growth on the eBay site. A late 2003 reorganization created a new business unit within PayPal—Merchant Services—to provide payment solutions to small and large e-commerce merchants outside the eBay auction community. Starting in the second half of 2004, PayPal Merchant Services unveiled several initiatives to enroll online merchants outside the eBay auction community, including: * Lowering its transaction fee for high-volume merchants from 2.2% to 1.9% (while increasing the monthly transaction volume required to qualify for the lowest fee to $100,000) * Encouraging its users to recruit non-eBay merchants by increasing its referral bonus to a maximum of $1,000 (versus the previous $100 cap) * Persuading credit card gateway providers, including [[CyberSource]] and Retail Decisions USA, to include PayPal among their offerings to online merchants. * Hiring a new sales force to acquire large merchants such as [[Dell]], [[ITunes|Apple's iTunes]], and [[Yahoo! Store]]s, which hosted thousands of online merchants * Reducing fees for online music purchases and other "micropayments" * Launching PayPal Mobile, which allowed users to make payments using text messaging on their cell phones === Global reach === PayPal can be used in more than 200 countries/regions.{{cite web | url=https://www.paypal.com/al/webapps/mpp/country-worldwide | title=PayPal Global – All countries and markets – PayPal | publisher=PayPal | access-date=28 March 2017 | archive-date=October 8, 2020 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201008015800/https://www.paypal.com/al/webapps/mpp/country-worldwide | url-status=live }} Different countries have different conditions: ''Send only'' (Package Service allows sending only, valid in 97 countries), ''PayPal Zero'' (package suggests the possibility of enrollment, entry, and withdrawal of funds in foreign currency, but the user can not hold the balance PayPal account, operates in 18 countries), ''SRW Send – Receive – Withdrawal'' (the possibility of enrollment, input-output and the ability to keep your PayPal account balance in the currency and to transfer to the card when the user sees fit, operates in 41 countries) and ''Local Currency'' (SRW plus opportunity to conduct transactions in the local currency, 21 countries). ====
