2019|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190131040644/http://www.bandt.com.au/media/paypal-giving-fund-launches-australia|url-status=live}} == Digital marketing with PayPal == PayPal launches different marketing activities in various channels and emphasizes that consumers can use it in different ways.{{cite web|last1=Jennifer|first1=Faull|title=PayPal set to launch multi-channel campaign|url=http://www.thedrum.com/news/2013/05/31/paypal-set-launch-multi-channel-campaign|website=The Drum|access-date=15 March 2018|archive-date=March 16, 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180316151918/http://www.thedrum.com/news/2013/05/31/paypal-set-launch-multi-channel-campaign|url-status=live}} Its marketing includes [[Television advertisement|TV commercials]], [[outdoor advertising]], [[Facebook]], and [[display advertisement]]. PayPal provides free [[analytics]] to traders about the ways that consumers utilize [[online payments]].{{cite web|last1=Amy|first1=Gesenhues|title=PayPal's new Marketing Solutions tool sheds light on how shoppers use the online payment platform|url=https://marketingland.com/paypals-new-marketing-solutions-tool-sheds-light-shoppers-use-online-payment-platform-226918|website=Marketing Land|access-date=14 March 2018|date=24 October 2017|archive-date=March 16, 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180316214033/https://marketingland.com/paypals-new-marketing-solutions-tool-sheds-light-shoppers-use-online-payment-platform-226918|url-status=live}} Through the free tracking service, PayPal assists traders in targeting consumers. PayPal's code gathers the consumer information, which can be installed on the trader's website. Both PayPal and traders benefit from the free service. PayPal partners with [[Synchrony Financial]] to provide the [[Mastercard|PayPal Cashback Mastercard]], which offers 2% cash back to customers who use the card to make purchases both online and in physical stores.{{cite web|last1=Tyrone|first1=Stewart|title=Paypal launches first cashback credit card to target physical stores {{!}} Mobile Marketing Magazine|url=http://mobilemarketingmagazine.com/paypal-cashback-mastercard-credit-card|website=MobileMarketing|access-date=15 March 2018|archive-date=March 16, 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180316084736/http://mobilemarketingmagazine.com/paypal-cashback-mastercard-credit-card|url-status=live}} PayPal’s cashback financial service promotes the number of potential customers. [[Apple Inc.|Apple]] allows PayPal as a mode of payment for [[App Store (iOS)|App Store]], [[Apple Music]], [[iTunes]], and [[Apple Books]].{{cite web|last1=Alex|first1=Spencer|title=Apple brings PayPal to App Store, Apple Music and iTunes for the first time {{!}} Mobile Marketing Magazine|url=http://mobilemarketingmagazine.com/apple-brings-paypal-to-app-store-apple-music-and-itunes-for-the-first-time|website=MobileMarketing|date=July 12, 2017 |access-date=15 March 2018|archive-date=March 16, 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180316084828/http://mobilemarketingmagazine.com/apple-brings-paypal-to-app-store-apple-music-and-itunes-for-the-first-time|url-status=live}} PayPal can increase usage of Apple platforms. In addition, PayPal receives revenue from Apple services, especially from the App Store.{{cite web|last1=Ayoub|first1=Aouad|title=PayPal and Apple enter major partnership|url=http://uk.businessinsider.com/paypal-and-apple-enter-major-partnership-2017-7|website=[[Business Insider]]|access-date=15 March 2018|archive-date=March 11, 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180311180851/http://uk.businessinsider.com/paypal-and-apple-enter-major-partnership-2017-7|url-status=live}} Customers can use PayPal to make purchases by linking their PayPal accounts to their Apple IDs. == Regulation == Thiel, a founder of PayPal, has said that PayPal is not a bank because it does not engage in [[fractional-reserve banking]].{{cite web| url=http://ecorner.stanford.edu/authorMaterialInfo.html?mid=1036| title=Paypal is Not a Bank| date=21 January 2004| publisher=Entrepreneurial Thought Leader Speaker Series: ECorner| access-date=24 November 2014| archive-date=September 12, 2015| archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150912004512/http://ecorner.stanford.edu/authorMaterialInfo.html?mid=1036| url-status=dead}} Rather, PayPal's funds that have not been disbursed are kept in commercial interest-bearing checking accounts.{{cite news|last=Chu|first=Lenora|title=What PayPal does with your money|url=https://money.cnn.com/2008/02/26/smbusiness/paypal_float.fsb/|access-date=16 March 2014|newspaper=[[CNNMoney]]|date=February 26, 2008|archive-date=November 9, 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201109033057/https://money.cnn.com/2008/02/26/smbusiness/paypal_float.fsb/|url-status=live}} In the United States, PayPal is licensed as a [[money transmitter]], on a state-by-state basis.[https://www.zdnet.com/news/fdic-decides-paypals-no-bank/121346 FDIC decides PayPal's no bank] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141129191731/http://www.zdnet.com/news/fdic-decides-paypals-no-bank/121346 |date=November 29, 2014 }}. ZDNet (March 13, 2002). Retrieved on 2013-08-12.{{cite web |url=http://law.bepress.com/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1153&context=expresso |title=Bepress.com |access-date=January 20, 2011 |archive-date=December 4, 2010 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101204022629/http://law.bepress.com/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1153&context=expresso |url-status=live }} But state laws vary, as do their definitions of banks, narrow banks, money services businesses, and money transmitters. Although PayPal is not classified as a bank, the company is subject to some of the rules and regulations governing the financial industry, including [[Regulation E]] consumer protections and the [[USA PATRIOT Act]].Uniting and Strengthening America by Providing Appropriate Tools Required to Intercept and Obstruct Terrorism (USA Patriot Act) Act of 2001, Pub. L. No. 107-56, 115 Stat. 272 (2001) The most analogous regulatory source of law for PayPal transactions comes from [[Peer-to-peer banking|peer-to-peer]] (P2P) payments using [[Credit card|credit]] and [[debit cards]]. Ordinarily, a credit card transaction, specifically the relationship between the issuing bank and the cardholder, is governed by the [[Truth in Lending Act]] (TILA) 15 U.S.C. §§ 1601-1667f as implemented by Regulation Z, 12 C.F.R. 226, (TILA/Z). TILA/Z requires specific procedures for billing errors, dispute resolution, and limits cardholder liability for unauthorized charges.Margaret Jane Radin et al., Internet Commerce The Emerging Legal Framework 1174–1175 Foundation Press (2d ed. 2006) Similarly, the legal relationship between a debit cardholder and the issuing bank is regulated by the [[Electronic Funds Transfer Act]] (EFTA) 15 U.S.C. §§ 1693-1693r, as implemented by Regulation E, 12 C.F.R. 205, (EFTA/E). EFTA/E is directed at consumer protection and provides strict error resolution procedures. However, because PayPal is a ''payment intermediary'' and not otherwise regulated directly, TILA/Z and EFTA/E do not operate exactly as written once the credit/debit card transaction occurs via PayPal. Basically, unless a PayPal transaction is funded with a credit card, the consumer has no recourse in the event of fraud by the seller. In 2008, PayPal Europe was granted a Luxembourg banking license, which, under European Union law, allows it to conduct banking business throughout the EU.Article 23 of the EU's Banking Directive (Directive 2006/48/EC). It is therefore regulated as a bank by Luxembourg's banking supervisory authority, the [[Commission de Surveillance du Secteur Financier]] (CSSF).{{cite web |url=http://www.paymentsnews.com/2007/05/paypal_obtains_.html |title=PayPal Obtains Bank Charter for European Union |publisher=Paymentsnews.com |access-date=February 15, 2012 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130514103323/http://www.paymentsnews.com/2007/05/paypal_obtains_.html |archive-date=May 14, 2013 |url-status=dead }}{{cite web|last=Stevenson|first=Tom|title=PayPal becomes a bank to fight off Google|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/finance/markets/2808982/PayPal-becomes-a-bank-to-fight-off-Google.html |archive-url=https://ghostarchive.org/archive/20220110/https://www.telegraph.co.uk/finance/markets/2808982/PayPal-becomes-a-bank-to-fight-off-Google.html |archive-date=January 10, 2022 |url-access=subscription |url-status=live|work=[[The Daily Telegraph|The Telegraph]]|date=May 15, 2007 |access-date=September 24, 2012}}{{cbignore}}{{cite web |url=http://tamebay.com/2007/05/paypal-becomes-a-bank-no-longer-under-fsa.html |title=PayPal becomes a Bank, no longer under FSA : TameBay : eBay & ecommerce made easy |publisher=TameBay |date=May 15, 2007 |access-date=February 15, 2012 |archive-date=February 25, 2012 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120225044816/http://tamebay.com/2007/05/paypal-becomes-a-bank-no-longer-under-fsa.html |url-status=live }} All of the company's European accounts were transferred to PayPal's bank in Luxembourg in July 2007.{{cite web|last=Holahan |first=Catherine |url=http://www.businessweek.com/technology/content/jun2007/tc20070614_606853.htm?chan=technology_technology+index+page_top+stories |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070617191351/http://www.businessweek.com/technology/content/jun2007/tc20070614_606853.htm?chan=technology_technology+index+page_top+stories |url-status=dead |archive-date=June 17, 2007 |title=Businessweek.com |work=Bloomberg BusinessWeek |date=June 15, 2007 |access-date=January 20, 2011}} Prior to the move, PayPal had been registered in the United Kingdom as PayPal (Europe) Ltd, an entity which was licensed as an Electronic Money Issuer with the UK's [[Financial Services Authority]] (FSA) from 2004. This ceased in 2007, when the company moved to Luxembourg.{{cite web |url=http://www.fsa.gov.uk/register/firmBasicDetails.do?sid=99095 |title=FSA.gov.uk |publisher=FSA.gov.uk |access-date=January 20, 2011 |archive-date=April 29, 2011 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110429043505/http://www.fsa.gov.uk/register/firmBasicDetails.do?sid=99095 |url-status=dead }} In India, as of January 2010, PayPal has no cross-border money transfer authorization. In [[The New York Times]] article "India's Central Bank Stops Some PayPal Services", Reserve Bank of India spokesman Alpana Killawalla stated: "Providers of cross-border money transfer service need prior authorization from the Reserve Bank under the Payment and Settlement Systems Act, PayPal does not have our authorization."[https://www.nytimes.com/2010/02/11/business/global/11paypal.html NYtimes.com] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170701031808/http://www.nytimes.com/2010/02/11/business/global/11paypal.html |date=July 1, 2017 }} The New York Times, India's Central Bank Stops Some PayPal Services, by Heather Timmons and Claire Cain Miller, February 10, 2010, PayPal is not listed in the "Certificates of Authorisation issued by the Reserve Bank of India under the Payment and Settlement Systems Act, 2007 for Setting up and Operating Payment System in India".[http://rbi.org.in/scripts/PublicationsView.aspx?id=12043 RBI.org.in] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100219072245/http://rbi.org.in/scripts/PublicationsView.aspx?id=12043 |date=February 19, 2010 }} Certificates of Authorisation issued by the Reserve Bank of India under the Payment and Settlement Systems Act, 2007 for Setting up and Operating Payment System in India PaisaPay is an Indian sister service to PayPal. It is also owned by eBay.{{cite web|last=Ebay Helpfile on Paisapay|title=Ebay.in help file on Paisapay|url=http://pages.ebay.in/ebayexplained/paisapay.html|access-date=October 15, 2013|archive-date=October 29, 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131029195911/http://pages.ebay.in/ebayexplained/paisapay.html|url-status=live}} PaisaPay makes possible payments from abroad by PayPal account holders to Indian sellers on eBay.in. In Australia, PayPal is licensed as an [[authorised deposit-taking institution]] (ADI) and is thus subject to Australian banking laws and regulations.{{cite web|url=http://www.apra.gov.au/adi/Documents/cfdocs/PayPal-auth-and-conditions-2006.pdf|title=Authority to carry on banking business, ''Banking Act 1959''|access-date=September 10, 2012|archive-date=October 24, 2012|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121024150622/http://apra.gov.au/adi/Documents/cfdocs/PayPal-auth-and-conditions-2006.pdf|url-status=dead}} In Singapore, PayPal holds a stored value facility that does not require the approval of the [[Monetary Authority of Singapore]].{{cite web|url=https://www.paypal.com/sg/home|website=paypal.com/sg|title=PayPal|access-date=2019-08-10|archive-date=August 10, 2019|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190810022131/https://www.paypal.com/sg/home|url-status=live}} == Safety and protection policies == The PayPal Buyer Protection Policy states that customers may file a buyer complaint for not receiving an item or if the purchased item was significantly not as described. The customer can open a dispute within 180 days from the date of payment and escalate it to a claim within 20 days from opening the dispute. Buyers using a credit card might get a refund via [[chargeback]] from their credit-card company. However, in the UK, where such a purchaser is entitled to specific statutory protections (that the credit card company is a second party to the purchase and is therefore equally liable in law if the other party defaults or goes into liquidation) under Section 75 Consumer Credit Act 1974, the purchaser loses this legal protection if the card payment is processed via PayPal.{{cite web |last=Kukiewicz |first=Julia |url=https://www.choose.co.uk/money/guide/section-75-consumer-credit-act/ |title=Section 75: Credit card purchase protection |publisher=Choose |date=November 1, 2011 |access-date=November 1, 2011 |archive-date=May 14, 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220514111602/https://www.choose.co.uk/money/guide/section-75-consumer-credit-act/ |url-status=live }} Also, the Financial Ombudsman Service (for the U.K.) position is that section 75 protection does not apply where PayPal or any eMoney service becomes involved in the credit card transaction. This leaves consumers with no recourse to pursue their complaint with the Financial Ombudsman Service. They only would have recourse in the courts, but in any event they cannot because PayPal is incorporated in Luxembourg and, since the UK has left the EU, is now no longer within the jurisdiction of any UK Courts. The key issues that determine the applicability of section 75 are identified very clearly in Office of Fair Trading v Lloyds TSB Bank Plc and others [2006] EWCA Civ 268 7 and the [[Bank of Scotland]] v Alfred Truman (a firm) [2005] [EWHC] 583 (QB). This is a legal authority that section 75 protection does exist where one has paid on a credit card for a product, via an eMoney service.{{cite web |last=Miloseski-Reid |first=Paul |url=https://publications.parliament.uk/pa/cm201314/cmselect/cmhaff/70/70vw05.htm |title=Home Affairs Committee |publisher=publications.parliament.uk |date=July 29, 2013 |access-date=June 13, 2015 |archive-date=June 15, 2015 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150615071611/http://www.publications.parliament.uk/pa/cm201314/cmselect/cmhaff/70/70vw05.htm |url-status=live }} According to PayPal, it protects sellers in a limited fashion via the Seller Protection Policy. In general, the Seller Protection Policy is intended to protect the seller from certain kinds of chargebacks or complaints if the seller meets certain conditions, including proof of delivery to the buyer. PayPal states the Seller Protection Policy is "designed to protect sellers against claims by buyers of unauthorized payments and against claims of non-receipt of any merchandise". The policy includes a list of "Exclusions" which itself includes "Intangible goods", "Claims for receipt of goods 'not as described{{'"}}, and "Total reversals over the annual limit".{{cite web| url=https://www.paypal.com/us/webapps/mpp/paypal-safety-and-security| title=Buyer Protection & Seller Protection| publisher=PayPal| access-date=24 November 2014| archive-date=November 25, 2014| archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141125020810/https://www.paypal.com/us/webapps/mpp/paypal-safety-and-security| url-status=live}} There are also other restrictions in terms of the sale itself, the payment method and the destination country the item is shipped to (simply having a tracking mechanism is not sufficient to guarantee the Seller Protection Policy is in effect). The PayPal Seller Protection Policy does not provide the additional consumer protection afforded by UK consumer legislation ''(most notably the [[Consumer Rights Act 2015]])'' and in addition, it cannot be enforced in the Courts because PayPal operates from Luxembourg, outside all three of the UK legal jurisdictions.{{cite web| url=https://www.paypal.com/us/webapps/mpp/ua/useragreement-full| title=PayPal User Agreement| date=8 October 2014| publisher=PayPal| access-date=24 November 2014| archive-date=November 25, 2014| archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141125030826/https://www.paypal.com/us/webapps/mpp/ua/useragreement-full| url-status=live}} ==Security== === Security token === {{main|Security token}} In early 2006, PayPal introduced an optional [[Security token|security key]] as an additional precaution against fraud.{{cite magazine| url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/katevinton/2014/06/25/researchers-discover-vulnerability-in-paypals-two-factor-authentication/| title=Researchers Discover Vulnerability in PayPal's Two-Factor Authentication| author=Kate Vinton| date=25 June 2014| magazine=Forbes| access-date=24 November 2014}} A user account tied to a security key has a modified login process. Account-holders enter their login ID and password as normal, but are then prompted to enter a six-digit code provided by a credit card sized hardware security key or a text message sent to the account holder's mobile phone. For convenience, users may append the code generated by the hardware key to their password in the login screen. This way they are not prompted for it on another page. This method is required for some services, such as when using PayPal through the eBay application on [[iPhone]]. This [[two-factor authentication]] is intended to make it difficult for an account to be compromised by a malicious third party without access to the physical security key, although it does not prevent the so-called [[Man in the Browser]] (MITB) attacks. However, the user (or malicious third party) can alternatively authenticate by providing the credit card or bank account number listed on their account. Thus, the PayPal implementation does not offer the security of true two-factor authentication.{{cite web| url=http://www.techhive.com/article/2058327/keep-your-paypal-account-safer-with-two-factor-authentication.html| title=Keep your PayPal account safer with two-factor authentication| author=Nick Mediati| date=29 October 2013| publisher=TechHive| access-date=24 November 2014| archive-date=October 30, 2014| archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141030070820/http://www.techhive.com/article/2058327/keep-your-paypal-account-safer-with-two-factor-authentication.html| url-status=live}} === MTAN === It is also possible to use a mobile phone to receive an [[mTAN]] (Mobile Transaction Authentication Number) via [[SMS]].{{cite web| title=PayPal Security Key – PayPal| url=https://www.paypal.com/cgi-bin/webscr?cmd=xpt/Marketing_CommandDriven/securitycenter/PayPalSecurityKey-outside| access-date=August 18, 2009| archive-date=October 21, 2010| archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101021224410/https://www.paypal.com/cgi-bin/webscr?cmd=xpt/Marketing_CommandDriven/securitycenter/PayPalSecurityKey-outside| url-status=live}} Use of a security code that is sent to the account holder's mobile phone is currently free.[http://www.moonlightceo.com/paypal-secrets/ MoonlightCEO.com] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140701002217/http://www.moonlightceo.com/paypal-secrets/ |date=July 1, 2014 }} Moonlight CEO, PayPal Secrets, October 28, 2013 == Fraud == As early as 2001, PayPal had substantial problems with [[online fraud]], especially international [[hacker]]s who were hacking into PayPal accounts and transferring small amounts of money out of multiple accounts. Standard solutions for merchant and banking fraud might use government criminal sanctions to pursue the fraudsters. But with PayPal losing millions of dollars each month to fraud while experiencing difficulties with using the [[FBI]] to pursue cases of international fraud, PayPal developed a fraud monitoring system to detect potentially fraudulent transactions.{{cite news|last1=Morisy|first1=Michael|title=How PayPal Boosts Security with Artificial Intelligence|url=http://www.technologyreview.com/news/545631/how-paypal-boosts-security-with-artificial-intelligence/|access-date=28 January 2016|work=MIT Technology Review|date=25 January 2016|archive-date=January 28, 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160128015006/http://www.technologyreview.com/news/545631/how-paypal-boosts-security-with-artificial-intelligence/|url-status=dead}} This development of fraud monitoring software at PayPal led Peter Thiel to create [[Palantir Technologies|Palantir]], a big-data security company whose original mission was to "reduce terrorism while preserving civil liberties."{{cite book |last1=Thiel |first1=Peter A. |title=Zero to one : notes on startups, or how to build the future |year=2014 |location=New York |isbn=978-0-8041-3929-8 |edition=First}} === 150,000 PayPal cards frozen === In 2015, 150,000 Spanish cardholders had their funds frozen in an apparent fraud case involving a PayPal service provider, Younique Money, which was the de facto administrator of the cards. Previously, PayPal had charged €15 to all its card users without authorization (150,000 users). As of March 2015, most funds had not been returned.{{cite web|url=http://www.ocu.org/dinero/tarjetas/noticias/paypal-prepago|title=Paypal prepago deja de estar operativa|access-date=5 September 2015|archive-date=March 18, 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150318101631/http://www.ocu.org/dinero/tarjetas/noticias/paypal-prepago|url-status=live}}{{cite web|url=http://cadenaser.com/programa/2015/03/06/ser_consumidor/1425647549_395678.html|title=OCU denuncia a YoUnique Money ante el Banco de España|author=Cadena Ser|date=6 March 2015|work=Cadena Ser|access-date=5 September 2015|archive-date=September 6, 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150906040752/http://cadenaser.com/programa/2015/03/06/ser_consumidor/1425647549_395678.html|url-status=live}}{{cite web|url=http://www.lavanguardia.com/economia/20150216/54427286227/younique-money-perdio-su-autorizacion-para-operar-por-irregularidad-contable.html|title=El Banco de España retira la licencia a Younique Money para emitir tarjetas Paypal|work=LA VANGUARDIA|date=February 16, 2015|access-date=5 September 2015|archive-date=April 2, 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150402090124/http://www.lavanguardia.com/economia/20150216/54427286227/younique-money-perdio-su-autorizacion-para-operar-por-irregularidad-contable.html|url-status=live}} == Criticism and controversies == {{See also|Criticism of eBay}} In 2003, PayPal voluntarily ceased serving as a payment intermediary between gambling websites and their online customers. At the time of this cessation, it was the largest payment processor for online gambling transactions. In 2010, PayPal resumed accepting such transactions, but only in those countries where online gambling is legal, and only for sites which are properly licensed to operate in said jurisdictions.{{Cite web|title=Internet bingo guide to PayPal|url=http://internet-bingo.co/payment-options/paypal/|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131029190241/http://internet-bingo.co/payment-options/paypal/|archive-date=2013-10-29|access-date=2023-04-28|website=www.internet-bingo.co|language=en}} Since at least 2005, PayPal has maintained an Acceptable Use policy which disallows "transactions involving... items that are considered obscene... [or] certain sexually oriented materials or services." Their enforcement of the policy has been a constant source of controversy between PayPal and people within or related to the sex industry. In 2014, PayPal notified subscription service provider [[Patreon]] that it was moving to cease integration with Patreon as a platform as the result of Patreon permitting "adult content" on their platform. Patreon then removed access to PayPal services for creators who produced sexual content.{{cite web |author1=Violet Blue |title=PayPal, Square and big banking's war on the sex industry |url=https://www.engadget.com/2015-12-02-paypal-square-and-big-bankings-war-on-the-sex-industry.html |website=engadget.com |date=July 19, 2019 |publisher=Verizon Media Inc. |access-date=6 June 2021 |archive-date=June 6, 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210606073433/https://www.engadget.com/2015-12-02-paypal-square-and-big-bankings-war-on-the-sex-industry.html |url-status=live }} If an account is subject to fraud or unauthorized use, PayPal puts the "Limited Access" designation on the account. PayPal has had several notable cases in which the company has frozen the account of users such as [[Richard Kyanka]], owner of the website [[Something Awful]], in September 2005,{{cite web |url=https://www.ecommercetimes.com/story/46325.html |title=E-Commerce News: Security: Feds Investigating Fraudulent Katrina-Related Web Sites |date=September 26, 2005 |publisher=Ecommercetimes.com |access-date=January 20, 2011 |archive-date=April 27, 2011 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110427041009/http://www.ecommercetimes.com/story/46325.html |url-status=live }} [[Cryptome]] in March 2010,{{cite web |last=Orlowski |first=Andrew |url=https://www.theregister.co.uk/2010/03/08/paypal_cryptome_ko/ |title=Theregister.co.uk |publisher=Theregister.co.uk |date=March 8, 2010 |access-date=January 20, 2011 |archive-date=March 15, 2011 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110315054658/http://www.theregister.co.uk/2010/03/08/paypal_cryptome_ko/ |url-status=live }}{{cite web |last=Orlowski |first=Andrew |url=https://www.theregister.co.uk/2010/03/10/cryptome_paypal/ |title=Theregister.co.uk |publisher=Theregister.co.uk |date=March 10, 2010 |access-date=January 20, 2011 |archive-date=January 9, 2011 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110109084648/http://www.theregister.co.uk/2010/03/10/cryptome_paypal/ |url-status=live }}{{cite web |last=Orlowski |first=Andrew |url=https://www.theregister.co.uk/2010/03/16/cryptome_paypal/ |title=Theregister.co.uk |publisher=Theregister.co.uk |date=March 16, 2010 |access-date=January 20, 2011 |archive-date=April 2, 2011 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110402094551/http://www.theregister.co.uk/2010/03/16/cryptome_paypal/ |url-status=live }} or [[April Winchell]], the owner of [[Regretsy]], in December 2011. The account was reinstated, and PayPal apologized and donated to her cause.{{cite news | url=http://consumerist.com/2011/12/paypal-rains-on-regretsys-secret-santa-campaign-over-use-of-wrong-button.html | title=PayPal Rains on Regretsy's Secret Santa Campaign Over Use of Wrong Button | work=The Consumerist | date=December 5, 2011 | access-date=November 6, 2011 | author=Morran, Chris | archive-date=December 6, 2011 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111206224125/http://consumerist.com/2011/12/paypal-rains-on-regretsys-secret-santa-campaign-over-use-of-wrong-button.html | url-status=live }} In September 2010, PayPal froze the account of [[Markus Persson]], a [[Minecraft]] developer. Persson publicly said that he had not received a clear explanation from PayPal as to why the account was frozen, and that PayPal was threatening to keep the money in the account if they found any suspicious activity. His account contained around €600,000 ($655,842 USD).{{cite news |url=http://www.rockpapershotgun.com/2010/09/10/paypal-freezes-minecraft-devs-600k-euros/ |title=PayPal Freezes Minecraft Dev's 600k Euros |website=[[Rock Paper Shotgun]] |date=September 10, 2010 |access-date=January 20, 2011 |archive-date=February 22, 2011 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110222032559/http://www.rockpapershotgun.com/2010/09/10/paypal-freezes-minecraft-devs-600k-euros/ |url-status=live }} PayPal's partner [[MasterCard]] ceased taking donations to [[WikiLeaks]] in 2010, and PayPal also suspended, and later permanently restricted, payments to the website after the [[United States Department of State|U.S. State Department]] said WikiLeaks was engaged in illegal activities. Online supporters and activists retaliated by subjecting PayPal and MasterCard, along with other companies, to coordinated [[cyberattack|cyber attacks]].{{cite news | url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2010/dec/08/operation-payback-mastercard-website-wikileaks | location=London | work=[[The Guardian]] | first1=Esther | last1=Addley | first2=Josh | last2=Halliday | title=Operation Payback cripples MasterCard site in revenge for WikiLeaks ban | date=December 8, 2010 | access-date=December 28, 2014 | archive-date=August 17, 2014 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140817052546/http://www.theguardian.com/media/2010/dec/08/operation-payback-mastercard-website-wikileaks | url-status=live }} In February 2011, PayPal [[wikt:unbanned|unbanned]] the account of a website that supports [[List of Iraq War resisters|Iraq War resisters]] after it had enough information to fulfill its [[know your customer]] guidelines. The [[Chelsea Manning]] Support Network claimed the backdown was a reaction to a petition to the company to reinstate the account.{{cite web |url=https://www.cnet.com/news/paypal-reinstates-bradley-manning-support-group-account/ |author=Lance Whitney |title=PayPal reinstates Bradley Manning support group account |date=February 25, 2011 |website=CNET |access-date=December 28, 2014 |archive-date=January 12, 2015 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150112235408/http://www.cnet.com/news/paypal-reinstates-bradley-manning-support-group-account/ |url-status=live }} In May 2013, PayPal declined to pay a reward offered in its Bug Bounty Program{{cite web |url=https://www.paypal.com/us/webapps/mpp/security/reporting-security-issues |publisher=PayPal |title=Security Researchers Bug Bounty Program |access-date=May 27, 2013 |archive-date=June 14, 2013 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130614162910/https://www.paypal.com/us/webapps/mpp/security/reporting-security-issues |url-status=live }} to a 17-year-old German student who had reported a [[cross-site scripting]] flaw on its site.{{cite magazine |url=http://www.pcworld.com/article/2039940/paypal-denies-teenager-reward-for-finding-website-bug.html |title=PayPal denies teenager reward for finding website bug |magazine=PCWorld |date=May 28, 2013 |access-date=May 29, 2013}} The company wrote that the vulnerability had been previously reported, and chastised the youth for disclosing the issue to the public, but, uniquely, sent him a "Letter of recognition" for the discovery.{{cite web|url=https://threatpost.com/paypal-to-fix-xss-flaw-but-no-reward-for-researcher/100802/|title=PayPal to Fix XSS Flaw, But No Reward For used PayPal to collect the funds they raised on [[crowdfunding]] platforms like [[Kickstarter]] and [[Indiegogo]] reported difficulty in being able to withdraw the money. PayPal discontinued payments to [[Pornhub]] models on November 14, 2019,{{cite news|access-date=2019-11-15|title=PayPal halts payment support to PornHub models|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-paypal-pornhub-idUSKBN1XO2SV|newspaper=[[Reuters]]|date=14 November 2019|first=Vibhuti|last=Sharma|archive-date=November 15, 2019|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20191115132800/https://www.reuters.com/article/us-paypal-pornhub-idUSKBN1XO2SV|url-status=live}} alleging that "Pornhub has made certain business payments through PayPal without seeking our permission".{{cite web|first1=Samantha|last1=Cole|access-date=2019-11-15|title=PayPal Pulls Out of Pornhub, Hurting 'Hundreds of Thousands' of Performers|url=https://www.vice.com/en_us/article/d3abgv/paypal-pulls-out-of-pornhub-payments|date=14 November 2019|website=[[Vice (magazine)|Vice]]|archive-date=November 15, 2019|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20191115132750/https://www.vice.com/en_us/article/d3abgv/paypal-pulls-out-of-pornhub-payments|url-status=live}} Pornhub criticized the decision as one that affected "over a hundred thousand performers who rely on them for their livelihoods", and steered its payees toward other payment options.{{cite web|first1=Jay|last1=Peters|access-date=2019-11-15|title=PayPal abruptly cuts off Pornhub's payroll, leaving performers with few payment options|url=https://www.theverge.com/2019/11/14/20965167/paypal-pornhub-payroll-model-program-payment-options-paxum-verge-performers|date=14 November 2019|website=[[The Verge]]|archive-date=November 15, 2019|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20191115132759/https://www.theverge.com/2019/11/14/20965167/paypal-pornhub-payroll-model-program-payment-options-paxum-verge-performers|url-status=live}} In September 2020, PayPal issued new terms of service which introduced a fee for inactive accounts in 19 countries. In September 2022, PayPal shut the accounts of the British social commentator [[Toby Young]], and two connected organisations: the [[Free Speech Union]] and ''[[The Daily Sceptic]]'' website. PayPal said that the accounts were closed because of breaches of its acceptable use policy, apparently because of alleged [[COVID-19 vaccine misinformation and hesitancy|misinformation about COVID-19 vaccines]].{{cite news|author=James Beal|date=22 September 2022|access-date=2022-09-23|title=PayPal Free Speech Union accounts shut over Covid 'misinformation'|newspaper=[[The Times]]|url=https://www.thetimes.co.uk/article/paypal-free-speech-union-accounts-shut-over-covid-misinformation-90bzf2b2g|issn=0140-0460|via=www.thetimes.co.uk|archive-date=September 23, 2022|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220923054224/https://www.thetimes.co.uk/article/paypal-free-speech-union-accounts-shut-over-covid-misinformation-90bzf2b2g|url-status=live}} PayPal reversed the decision a few days later.{{Cite tweet |user=SpeechUnion|author=Free Speech Union |number=1574821962383253504 |title=PayPal has just reversed its decision to deplatform the Free Speech Union and apologised.}} {{cite news|first1=Tony|last1=Diver|first2=Henry|last2=Bodkin|access-date=2022-09-28|title=PayPal reinstates Free Speech Union accounts after being accused of 'politically motivated' ban|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/politics/2022/09/27/paypal-reinstates-free-speech-union-accounts-accused-politically/|newspaper=[[The Daily Telegraph|The Telegraph]]|date=27 September 2022|issn=0307-1235|via=www.telegraph.co.uk|archive-date=September 28, 2022|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220928013423/https://www.telegraph.co.uk/politics/2022/09/27/paypal-reinstates-free-speech-union-accounts-accused-politically/|url-status=live}} In October 2022, PayPal published an update to their acceptable use policy which included a $2,500 fine for the accounts of users PayPal deemed to have been promoting "misinformation". Former PayPal president [[David A. Marcus]] criticized the change, tweeting that "PayPal's new AUP goes against everything I believe in". [[Elon Musk]], co-founder of X.com, which later merged with Confinity to form PayPal, also criticized the change. Following media scrutiny and criticism on social media, PayPal removed the updated policy from their website, stating: "An AUP notice recently went out in error that included incorrect information. PayPal is not fining people for misinformation and this language was never intended to be inserted in our policy. Our teams are working to correct our policy pages."{{Cite news |last=Caroline |first=Downey |date=October 8, 2022 |title=PayPal Pulls Back, Says It Won't Fine Customers $2,500 for 'Misinformation' after Backlash |work=National Review |url=https://www.nationalreview.com/news/new-paypal-policy-permits-company-to-fine-users-2500-for-misinformation/ |access-date=October 9, 2022 |archive-date=October 8, 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20221008232157/https://www.nationalreview.com/news/new-paypal-policy-permits-company-to-fine-users-2500-for-misinformation/ |url-status=live }}{{Cite web |last=De Wei |first=Low |date=2022-10-10 |title=PayPal Says It Never Intended to Fine Users for 'Misinformation' |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2022-10-10/paypal-misinformation-fines-musk-criticized-were-published-by-mistake |access-date=2022-10-11 |website=[[Bloomberg News|Bloomberg]]|archive-date=October 11, 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20221011073021/https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2022-10-10/paypal-misinformation-fines-musk-criticized-were-published-by-mistake |url-status=live }} == Litigation == In March 2002, two PayPal account holders separately sued the company for alleged violations of the Electronic Funds Transfer Act (EFTA) and California law. Most of the allegations concerned PayPal's dispute resolution procedures. The two lawsuits were merged into one class-action lawsuit (In re: PayPal litigation). An informal settlement was reached in November 2003, and a formal settlement was signed on June 11, 2004. The settlement requires that PayPal change its business practices (including changing its dispute resolution procedures to make them EFTA-compliant), as well as making a US$9.25 million payment to members of the class. PayPal denied any wrongdoing.{{cite web|url=http://paypalsucks.com/files/PayPalSettlementAgreement.pdf|title=Settlement Agreement|date=June 11, 2004|access-date=August 6, 2008|archive-date=June 26, 2011|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110626085453/http://paypalsucks.com/files/PayPalSettlementAgreement.pdf|url-status=dead}} In June 2003, [[Stamps.com]] filed a lawsuit against PayPal and eBay claiming breach of contract, breach of the implied covenants of good faith and fair dealing, and interference with contract, among other claims. In a 2002 license agreement, Stamps.com and PayPal agreed that Stamps.com technology would be made available to allow PayPal users to buy and print postage online from their PayPal accounts. Stamps.com claimed that PayPal did not live up to its contractual obligations and accused eBay of interfering with PayPal and Stamps.com's agreement, hence Stamps.com's reasoning for including eBay in the suit.{{cite news| url=https://www.nytimes.com/2003/06/26/business/technology-briefing-internet-stampscom-files-breach-contract-suit-against-ebay.html| title=Technology Briefing, Internet: Stamps.com Files Breach Of Contract Suit Against eBay| date=26 June 2003| newspaper=[[The New York Times]]| access-date=24 November 2014| archive-date=July 1, 2017| archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170701010719/http://www.nytimes.com/2003/06/26/business/technology-briefing-internet-stampscom-files-breach-contract-suit-against-ebay.html| url-status=live}}{{cite web|url=http://www.stamps.com/company/news/20030625p/|title=Stamps.com Asserts Breach of Contract Claim Against PayPal and eBay|date=April 23, 2008|access-date=August 27, 2007|archive-date=October 9, 2007|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071009035928/http://www.stamps.com/company/news/20030625p/|url-status=live}} Craig Comb and two others filed a class action against PayPal in ''Craig Comb, et al. v. PayPal Inc.''. They sued, alleging illegal misappropriation of customer accounts and detailed their customer service experiences, including freezing deposited funds for up to 180 days until disputes were resolved by PayPal. PayPal argued that the plaintiffs were required to arbitrate their disputes under the [[American Arbitration Association]]'s Commercial Arbitration Rules. The court ruled against PayPal, stating that "the User Agreement and arbitration clause are substantively unconscionable under California law."{{cite web|url=http://pub.bna.com/eclr/021227.htm|title=Comb v. PayPal Inc.|date=January 21, 2007|access-date=July 29, 2006|archive-date=July 15, 2006|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060715192615/http://pub.bna.com/eclr/021227.htm|url-status=live}} Paypal agreed to pay $9.25 million as a result of the case.{{Cite web|last=Christophi|first=Helen|date=2017-03-27|title=Judge Approves $4M Deal Over Closed PayPal Accounts|url=https://www.courthousenews.com/judge-approves-4m-deal-closed-paypal-accounts/|access-date=2020-08-09|language=en-US|archive-date=September 5, 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200905122921/https://www.courthousenews.com/judge-approves-4m-deal-closed-paypal-accounts/|url-status=live}} In September 2002, [[Bank One Corporation]] sued PayPal for allegedly infringing its cardless payment system patents.[http://www.pcworld.com/article/104855/paypal_hit_with_patent_infringement_lawsuit.html PayPal Hit With Patent Infringement Lawsuit] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120107065400/http://www.pcworld.com/article/104855/paypal_hit_with_patent_infringement_lawsuit.html |date=January 7, 2012 }} – PC World, September 10, 2002 The following year, PayPal countersued, claiming that Bank One's online bill-payment system was an infringement against PayPal's online bill-payment patent, issued in 1998.{{cite news|url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9C0DEFD91F3DF932A35753C1A9659C8B63|title=Internet: PayPal Sues Bank One Over Patent Infringement|date=April 23, 2008|work=[[The New York Times]]|access-date=February 18, 2017|archive-date=December 6, 2008|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081206165949/http://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9C0DEFD91F3DF932A35753C1A9659C8B63|url-status=live}} The two companies agreed on a [[Settlement (litigation)|settlement]] in October 2003.[http://www.law360.com/financialservices/articles/110/ebay-s-paypal-bank-one-settle-patent-suit eBay, Bank One Settle Patent Suit] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111007040111/http://www.law360.com/financialservices/articles/110/ebay-s-paypal-bank-one-settle-patent-suit |date=October 7, 2011 }} – Law360, October 20, 2003 In November 2003, [[AT&T Corporation]] filed suit against eBay and PayPal claiming that their payment systems infringed an AT&T patent, filed in 1991 and granted in 1994.{{cite web|url=https://www.cnet.com/news/at-38t-sues-ebay-paypal-over-patent/|first=Paul|last=Festa|title=AT&T sues eBay, PayPal over patent|date=April 23, 2008|access-date=February 18, 2020|archive-date=September 7, 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200907211853/https://www.cnet.com/news/at-38t-sues-ebay-paypal-over-patent/|url-status=live}} The case was settled out of court the following month, with the terms of the settlement undisclosed.[http://news.cnet.com/2100-1038_3-5133886.html eBay, Tumbleweed settle patent suit] {{Webarchive|url=https://archive.today/20130119140213/http://news.cnet.com/2100-1038_3-5133886.html |date=January 19, 2013 }} – CNET, December 23, 2003 In June 2011, PayPal and Israel Credit Cards-Cal Ltd. were sued for [[New Israeli Shekel|NIS]] 16 million. The claimants accused PayPal of deliberately failing to notify its customers that ICC-Cal was illegally charging them for currency conversion fees.{{cite news|last=Katzovitch|first=Guy|title=ICC-Cal, Paypal sued in Tel Aviv court for NIS 16m|url=http://www.globes.co.il/serveen/globes/docview.asp?did=1000656812&fid=1725|access-date=June 23, 2011|newspaper=[[Globes (newspaper)|Globes]]|date=June 22, 2011|quote=A NIS 16 million lawsuit was filed yesterday with the Tel Aviv District Court against Israel Credit Cards-Cal Ltd. (ICC-Cal) (Visa) and PayPal Inc., and the claimants have asked the court to recognize it as a class-action suit.|archive-date=October 29, 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131029183826/http://www.globes.co.il/serveen/globes/docview.asp?did=1000656812&fid=1725|url-status=live}} A class-action lawsuit filed in 2010 was settled in 2016, in which the plaintiffs contested PayPal's "holds" on funds. PayPal has proposed a settlement in the amount of $3.2 million in Zepeda v. PayPal which has yet to be ratified. As part of the settlement, the company agreed to change some of its policies.{{Cite web|url=http://www.ecommercebytes.com/cab/abn/y16/m01/i15/s03|title=PayPal Agrees to Change Business Practices in Lawsuit Settlement|access-date=September 15, 2016|archive-date=September 16, 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160916012853/http://www.ecommercebytes.com/cab/abn/y16/m01/i15/s03|url-status=dead}} === CFPB consent === On 21 May 2015, PayPal agreed that PayPal Credit would pay a $25 million fine to settle a complaint filed in federal court by the [[Consumer Financial Protection Bureau]]. The complaint alleged that consumers using PayPal were signed up for PayPal credit accounts without their knowledge or consent, that PayPal had promised discounts and payment options the consumers never received, and that users trying to sign up for the regular, non-credit, PayPal accounts were signed up for credit accounts instead.{{cite news|last1=Marte|first1=Jonnelle|title=CFPB seeks to fine PayPal $25 million over credit allegations|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/get-there/wp/2015/05/19/agency-wants-to-fine-paypal-25-million-to-settle-credit-allegations/|access-date=21 Jan 2016|newspaper=[[The Washington Post]]|date=May 19, 2015|archive-date=January 23, 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160123150656/https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/get-there/wp/2015/05/19/agency-wants-to-fine-paypal-25-million-to-settle-credit-allegations/|url-status=live}} The complaint was filed in the [[United States District Court for the District of Maryland]], which ordered PayPal Credit to refund $15 million to consumers and to pay a $10 million fine. == See also
